instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1706: What is A1706? A1706 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2016, Mid 2017 with EMC 3071, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00239, 820-00923..
definitions.820-00923: What is 820-00923? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.CPUVR_PGOOD: What is CPUVR_PGOOD? CPU_VR_PGOOD Is a signal present when CPU_VR_EN is presenT. CPU_VR_PGOOD is a prerequisite along with ALL_SYS_PWRGD to create PM_S0_PGOOD and PM_PCH_PWROK and PM_PCH_SYS_PWROK which are necessary for the machine to turn on and boot..
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A sudden death - missing vcore - 20V - 0.25A
threads.message:
The Logicboard have no visible corrosion or burn marks.
The whole machine is clean.... I mean CLEAN! No dust in the fins!
I'm the first opened it.

No shorts on the coils!
All the S0-lines comes up except:
<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  [COLOR=rgb(235, 107, 86)]=0V [/COLOR]    4.8Ohms tg
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> [COLOR=rgb(235, 107, 86)]=0V[/COLOR] 2.8Ohms tg
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> [COLOR=rgb(226, 80, 65)]=0V[/COLOR]   6.5Ohms tg

I get 20V / 0.25A on the Amp meter without battery.
I tried to boot in DFU-mode without success.

The power button works as i can turn the S0-rails on/off.
The heat sink gets slightly warm over time.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A sudden death - missing vcore - 20V - 0.25A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPVCCGT_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  will only appear under graphics load, like playing YouTube videos.
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  must appear before VCORE (<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> ).
All these voltages are controlled by <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

Check if you get correct voltages for <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/20/70.

Can be CPU problem, or BIOS corruption.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A sudden death - missing vcore - 20V - 0.25A
threads.message:
OK as I said the optical inspection of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7210</CHIP>/20/70 is witout any doubts.
I checked now all the VIN-pins, VCC-pins, EN-pin and pgood-pin....
All the pins have the voltage they should have.
I would like to learn more about the <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>-ic. It seams it is responsible for the vcore-lines and has a lot of other I/O lines. 
Witch of these lines should I test next?
If this doesn't give me a hint, I will try to flash the BIOS tomorrow. I have allready a donor-BIOS and I have to clean the ME-region before flashing.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A sudden death - missing vcore - 20V - 0.25A
threads.message:
"I checked now all the VIN-pins, VCC-pins, EN-pin and pgood-pin....
All the pins have the voltage they should have. "
Do you mean to have voltage on all these pins?
I doubt to have high level on pgood of a missing output power rail...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A sudden death - missing vcore - 20V - 0.25A
threads.message:
Yes I mean every pin has the right voltage.
I double checked it: <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is indeed UP with 3.45V
<SIGNAL>CPU_VR_EN_R</SIGNAL>  3.35V
The PWM lines have 2.7V
None of the SENSE-lines have any voltage....

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A sudden death - missing vcore - 20V - 0.25A
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD</SIGNAL> is indeed UP with 3.45V "
This indicates good VCORE, which is not present in your case.
It is only possible if bad solder on pin 47/<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
You can have more bad solders...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A sudden death - missing vcore - 20V - 0.25A
threads.message:
I replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> with minor changes.....
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> came up = [COLOR=rgb(184, 49, 47)]1.1V[/COLOR]
But <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  =[COLOR=rgb(184, 49, 47)]0V[/COLOR]
And now <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = [COLOR=rgb(184, 49, 47)]0V[/COLOR]

[COLOR=rgb(0, 0, 0)]Now I get 20V / 0.36Aon the amp meter....
How I get the vcore back?[/COLOR]
Should I expect a dead CPU?
Or should I try my luck with flashing the BIOS?
______________________________________________________________

OK flashing the BIOS changed nothing!
I've another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> liquid damage that I fixed today and I compered [B]ALL[/B] the pins of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>:

[ATTACH type="full" width="585px"]59244[/ATTACH]

The only big difference that I see is PIN 34.
But <CHIP>U7270</CHIP> is working since [B]<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>[/B] is [B]1,1V[/B]
I don't know what else to check....
Is this a rabbit hole to hell???

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A sudden death - missing vcore - 20V - 0.25A
threads.message:
"How I get the vcore back? "
You didn't have VCORE before.
"<SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  =0V "
Power good of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> was bad instead.

"
I replaced <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> with minor changes.....
<SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> came up = 1.1V "
Not minor at all, you didn't have this voltage before.

"But <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>  =0V
And now <SIGNAL>CPUVR_PGOOD</SIGNAL> = 0V "
Power good signal is correct now, as you don't have VCORE.

Check <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>/23...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A sudden death - missing vcore - 20V - 0.25A
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R1720</RESISTOR> <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> are spot on 13,3K
But <RESISTOR>R7123</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7124</RESISTOR> are both 180K instead of 220K... I guess this is OK?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A sudden death - missing vcore - 20V - 0.25A
threads.message:
This could end in bad CPU...
You can try BIOS now, just for test.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1706</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> MacBook <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00923</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A sudden death - missing vcore - 20V - 0.25A
threads.message:
Finally I flashed the BIOS once again without any change.
So I have to stop further investigation due to lag of time and give it a NO-FIX here.
